author: By Jodi Levine
title: Make Like Matisse and Find the Flowers in Your Newspaper
description: Colorful paper blooms are easy to make and perfect for a spring table top.
content: “There are always flowers for those who want to see them,” Henri Matisse said. Even in this newspaper — just glue a skewer between two pieces of colored or painted newspaper and snip it into simple flower shapes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal and Hari Kumar
title: Maoist Insurgents Kill 23 Indian Forces in Ambush, Officials Say
description: The four-hour battle in a forested area of central India has revived concerns about a decades-old insurgency that had appeared largely contained.
content: NEW DELHI — At least 23 Indian security forces were killed in an ambush by Maoist militants in the central state of Chattisgarh, officials said on Sunday, reviving concerns around a decades-old insurgency that appeared to have been largely contained in recent years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Sarah Hughes
title: Virus Variants, Capitol Hill, N.C.A.A.: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: High-profile arrests rock Jordan.
content: The Jordanian government has arrested high-profile figures, including Sharif Hassan bin Zaid, a member of the royal family, and Bassem Awadallah, a former chief of the royal court, an unusual development in the normally stable Arab kingdom. Officials cited “the security and stability of Jordan” as reasons for the moves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rana F. Sweis, Adam Rasgon and Patrick Kingsley
title: Divided Kingdom: Jordan Shaken by Split Between King and Ex-Crown Prince
description: A royal rift laid bare. Key figures arrested. Rumors of a failed coup attempt. An intense bout of palace intrigue has knocked Jordan’s image as a reliable bulwark in a turbulent part of the world.
content: AMMAN, Jordan — The kingdom of Jordan has long been considered an oasis of relative stability in the Middle East. While wars and insurgencies flared in neighboring Syria and Iraq, Jordan was for decades considered a secure and dependable ally of the United States, a buffer against attacks on Israel, and a key interlocutor with Palestinians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norimitsu Onishi and Constant Méheut
title: An Outspoken Student Union Positions Itself at the Vanguard of a Changing France
description: To its critics, the 114-year-old Unef is the incarnation of the American-inspired ideas that threaten France’s founding principles. Its leaders say it is the future.
content: PARIS — A powerful government minister recently condemned it as an organization whose activities are racist and could lead to “fascism.” Lawmakers accused it of promoting “separatism” and of aligning with “Islamo-leftism” before demanding its dissolution.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Without Discussing It, My Partner and I Joined In for the Chorus’
description: Moved by a cartoon superhero, a funny moment on the subway and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Lessons From Lynchings
description: There’s a through-line from a noose on the neck to a knee on the neck.
content: There are many appalling narratives emerging from the trial of the former police officer Derek Chauvin in the killing of George Floyd.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: This Easter, Hope to Rebuild Wary Flocks and Replenish Spent Coffers
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, April 4, 2021.
content: “Pledges are not necessarily dramatically down, but donations given to the collection plate are hopelessly down.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Psychedelic Experience
description: Zhouqin Burnikel opens our solving week.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — I have been craving a Zhouqin Burnikel puzzle for a while now. Solving a crossword by Ms. Burnikel is like slipping on a comfortable, well-loved sweater: warm, easy to move around in and it puts a smile on one’s face. Her last Times puzzle ran in July 2020, and it’s nice to solve her puzzles again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Winfred Rembert, 75, Dies; Turned Painful Memories Into Art
description: Decades after nearly being lynched in rural Georgia, he began recreating vivid scenes from his life by carving figures into leather.
content: Winfred Rembert survived a near-lynching in rural Georgia in 1967. Just 21, he had been stripped of his clothes by a mob of white men and hoisted upside down from a tree, a noose around his ankles. One man came at him with a knife and nearly castrated him, sending blood gushing down his body.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Pietsch and Marie Fazio
title: ‘Imminent’ Collapse of Wastewater Reservoir in Florida Forces Evacuations
description: A potential deluge of nearly 400 million gallons of water from a former phosphate mine threatened homes south of Tampa on Saturday, officials warned.
content: A reservoir in Florida that holds nearly 400 million gallons of wastewater from a former phosphate mine was leaking on Saturday, prompting hundreds of evacuations, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Weiner
title: The Confidence, Speed and Shooting of Aari McDonald
description: McDonald has carried No. 3 seed Arizona to the N.C.A.A. tournament final against top-seeded Stanford, beating UConn in the semifinal. “The world is finally noticing what I can do,” she said.
content: Aari McDonald has always had an eye for the ball.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: Gonzaga Was Finally, Truly Tested. It Passed With a Buzzer-Beater Over U.C.L.A.
description: The Bulldogs will play Baylor for the N.C.A.A. men’s tournament championship on Monday night.
content: INDIANAPOLIS — As Gonzaga made its way through this pandemic season, with its stops and starts and tenor of uncertainty, it eyed an opportunity to stamp the season with a different sort of historical marker — an unbeaten season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Mele
title: Florida Officials Warn of 20-Foot ‘Wall of Water’ if Reservoir Breaches
description: The authorities on Sunday said they were making progress in draining a leaking wastewater pond south of Tampa but urged residents to heed evacuation warnings.
content: The authorities in Florida said on Sunday that they were making progress in their efforts to drain a leaking reservoir holding more than 300 million gallons of wastewater but warned that were it to breach, it could result in a 20-foot wall of water.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder, Jeré Longman and Gillian R. Brassil
title: Women’s Basketball Is a Renewed Flashpoint for an Embattled N.C.A.A.
description: Women’s college basketball has followed a similar competitive arc to the men’s game. But nearly 50 years after Title IX, it is still struggling for full acceptance in college sports.
content: The women’s basketball players of Immaculata often washed their own uniforms. They flew standby to save money, and sold pencils and toothbrushes to finance travel costs to their first national tournament. A collection of pail-pounding nuns made up a raucous cheering section.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: DMX on Life Support in ‘Vegetative State,’ Ex-Manager Says
description: The rapper, whose real name is Earl Simmons, was hospitalized after a heart attack, his lawyer said.
content: Earl Simmons, the rapper known as DMX, was on life support on Sunday afternoon and was in a “vegetative state,” said his former manager, who said she has been in contact with his family. Mr. Simmons’s longtime lawyer said he had been hospitalized after a heart attack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Finney Boylan
title: I Know Why I Am Here on Earth
description: My father died on Easter Sunday. His spirit is all around.
content: My father died, of melanoma, 35 years ago on the 30th of March. It was Easter Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norman Mayersohn
title: Driving Less? Make Sure Your Car Hasn’t Deteriorated During Lockdown
description: Many people may have deferred maintenance because their cars mostly sat around in the pandemic. But that creates its own ills.
content: You may have put off going to the doctor, the dentist, getting hair cuts, abandoned your commute and reduced your driving to essential errands during the pandemic. Staying put has most likely made you safer, but you weren’t doing any favors for your car, especially if you were also putting off maintenance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Blue Jays Capture Series Thanks to Homers by Guerrero, Grichuk
description: Domingo German of the Yankees went three inning in his first appearance since returning from a suspension.
content: Vladimir Guerrero Jr. dropped 42 pounds after an underwhelming 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas
title: Chicago to Release Video of Deadly Police Shooting of a 13-Year-Old
description: The shooting has tapped into a tide of anguish and frustration in Chicago neighborhoods that have been gripped by recurring gun violence.
content: On the night of March 28, Elizabeth Toledo thought her 13-year-old son, Adam, was finally home. He had returned after days away. She had even called the Chicago police to report him missing. But that Sunday night, she would later tell reporters, she saw him go into the room he shared with his brother.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Severson
title: Martha Lou Gadsden, Soul-Food Matriarch, Dies at 91
description: For 37 years she stirred the pot at Martha Lou’s Kitchen in Charleston, S.C., a modest restaurant that became known as a temple for Low Country cuisine.
content: It would be impossible to add up all the meals Martha Lou Gadsden cooked over her lifetime.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise
title: Amid Awakening, Asian-Americans Are Still Taking Shape as a Political Force
description: Divided by generation, ethnicity and class, but currently galvanized by a surge of racially motivated attacks, Asian-Americans are growing rapidly as political players.
content: When Mike Park first heard about the recent shootings in Atlanta, he felt angry and afraid. But almost immediately, he had another thought.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gillian R. Brassil
title: What to Watch For in the Women’s N.C.A.A. Basketball Final
description: Stanford will fight for its first title since 1992, while Arizona hopes for another stunner in its championship debut.
content: SAN ANTONIO — For the first time, two teams from the Pac-12 will fight for the national title in the N.C.A.A. women’s tournament final as top-seeded Stanford faces Arizona, a No. 3 seed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Nicole Hong
title: Biden Steps Up Federal Efforts to Combat Domestic Extremism
description: The administration has taken a series of steps to prioritize dealing with white supremacists and militias, especially after the Capitol riot on Jan. 6.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration is stepping up efforts to combat domestic extremism, increasing funding to prevent attacks, weighing strategies historically used against foreign terrorist groups and more openly warning the public about the threat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan and Ariana Drehsler
title: A Car Crash in the California Desert: How 13 Died Riding in One S.U.V.
description: In one of the deadliest border-related crashes in decades, many who died illustrate a new dynamic on the border: more migrants from Mexico.
content: HOLTVILLE, Calif. — The maroon Ford Expedition was so heavy its wheels spun at first in the soft desert sand as it cleared a breach in the border wall. It then sped down a dirt road as Mexico disappeared in the rearview mirror. Twenty-five people held on inside, many jammed on the floor, others hunched half-standing between them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Cowles
title: The Week in Business: Jobs Surge Back
description: Job growth rose to its highest level since last summer, buoyed by vaccines and federal aid.
content: Good morning and happy Easter. Here are the top stories in business and tech to know for the week ahead. — Charlotte Cowles
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: U.S. Taps Johnson & Johnson to Run Troubled Vaccine Plant
description: The extraordinary move came just days after officials learned the plant had ruined 15 million doses of Johnson & Johnson’s coronavirus vaccine.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration on Saturday put Johnson & Johnson in charge of a troubled Baltimore manufacturing plant that ruined 15 million doses of the Johnson & Johnson coronavirus vaccine and moved to stop the plant from making another vaccine by AstraZeneca, senior federal health officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech
title: ‘She Just Fell Down. And She Died.’
description: Myanmar’s security forces have killed more than 40 children since February. Here is the story of one, Aye Myat Thu. She was 10.
content: In the swelter of the hot season, U Soe Oo cracked open the coconut with practiced blows of his machete. Small hands reached out for the first slice, cool and slippery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: Gonzaga’s Buzzer-Beater a Reminder of the Hoopla That’s Missing
description: The noise of a capacity crowd erupting as Jalen Suggs’s overtime heave beat U.C.L.A. was only one of the many things absent from this tournament.
content: INDIANAPOLIS — When Jalen Suggs’s prayer masquerading as a 40-foot heave kissed off the glass and went through the net as the buzzer sounded late Saturday night, all he could think to do was mimic his basketball heroes, Kobe Bryant and Dwyane Wade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: On ‘S.N.L.,’ Britney Spears Renders Judgment on Matt Gaetz
description: The episode, hosted by Daniel Kaluuya, featured Chloe Fineman as the pop singer and Pete Davidson as the scandalized congressman.
content: It worked before, so “Saturday Night Live” did it again: this weekend’s broadcast opened with another installment of “Oops, You Did It Again,” a satirical talk show where Chloe Fineman, playing the pop singer Britney Spears, looks back on recent cultural and political controversies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryce Covert
title: Meet the New Cuomo. Same as the Old Cuomo.
description: We should have known who he was all along.
content: The nationwide fight for a $15 minimum wage began on the streets of New York City, when fast food workers staged a strike in 2012. It took Gov. Andrew Cuomo of New York four years to heed their demand. “New York is showing the way forward on economic justice,” he claimed, in 2016, when he finally got around to it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | April 5, 2021
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bhadra Sharma and Emily Schmall
title: As Climbers Return to Everest, an Already Dangerous Ascent Becomes Extra Perilous
description: Nepal, desperate for tourist money, says it has taken steps to prevent a coronavirus outbreak, including social distancing at base camp and  evacuation plans in case Covid-19 flares up.
content: KATHMANDU, Nepal — Mark Pattison played wide receiver for three National Football League teams in the 1980s. Now he wants to fulfill another dream: to climb all seven of the world’s highest peaks, including Mount Everest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $600,000
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Chicken yassa! Shakshuka with feta! Picadillo tacos! Whatever you choose, set yourself up to eat well this week.
content: Good morning. It is Easter today for some, and the last day of Passover for others. In Senegal, it is Independence Day, a celebration of that nation’s liberation from France in 1960. If a leg of lamb (above) is not on your menu for today, you might look to the Senegalese chef Pierre Thiam for a dinner idea, and to his recipe for chicken yassa in particular. He serves the dish over fonio, but rice or millet would do nicely. And a number of readers have suggested serving the dish with green olives as well.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Hughes
title: Does SoHo, Haven for Art and Wealth, Have Room for Affordable Housing?
description: The Manhattan neighborhood is locked in a contentious battle with city officials over whether, and how, it should change.
content: As a child growing up in SoHo, Akeela Azcuy remembers seeing her father, the drummer Rashied Ali, talking music with neighbors like the renowned jazz performer Ornette Coleman, who lived over on Grand Street.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley
title: Minority Entrepreneurs Struggled to Get Small-Business Relief Loans
description: A year after the Paycheck Protection Program started, studies show how its design hurt Black- and other minority-owned businesses.
content: Southern Bancorp is a lender serving the Arkansas and Mississippi Delta, where poverty rates are among the highest in America and decades of redlining shaped neighborhoods with little generational wealth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Review: Live Theater Returns, With Mike Daisey and His Beefs
description: The monologuist appeared onstage, indoors, in front of a real audience, on the first day possible. Maybe he shouldn’t have rushed.
content: Mike Daisey has been a monologuist for more than 20 years. Not continuously — though it has sometimes felt like it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Qin, Amy Chang Chien and Joy Dong
title: Taiwan Crash Investigators Focus on How Truck Fell in Train’s Path
description: Officials were trying to determine why the truck slid downhill from a construction site on Friday, resulting in the island’s deadliest rail disaster in decades.
content: HUALIEN, Taiwan — Two days after Taiwan’s deadliest rail disaster in decades, investigators were working on Sunday to determine why a truck had slipped downhill from a construction site into the path of an express train, resulting in the collision and derailment that killed dozens of people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Pope Francis’s Easter message urges world leaders to ensure universal access to vaccines.
description: He also noted the economic and social hardships of the pandemic, especially for the young.
content: Pope Francis delivered his annual “Urbi et Orbi” (“To the City and to the World”) Easter message to a small group of the faithful inside St. Peter’s Basilica on Sunday, while coronavirus pandemic prohibitions kept the usual audience of about 70,000 pilgrims away from St. Peter’s Square for a second year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Grillo and Danya Issawi
title: Celebrate Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg and Make Ratatouille
description: This week, whip up a drink while learning about art, meditate with the Asian Art Museum in San Francisco or listen to an audio play.
content: Here is a sampling of the week’s events and how to tune in (all times are Eastern). Note that events are subject to change after publication.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Johnson
title: Kristofer Schipper, Influential China Scholar, Dies at 86
description: A native of Holland, he helped change the understanding of Chinese religion and became a Taoist priest in the process.
content: Early in the afternoon on Thursday, in the southern Chinese city of Suzhou, more than 50 people gathered in a Taoist temple for a 10-hour ceremony to bid farewell to one of the most influential China scholars of recent times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: A Team in Anguish, a Vote and a Season Relinquished
description: The pandemic led to tough decisions for many college sports programs. Here is a look at how and why one of them, the Dixie State women’s basketball team, chose to stop playing.
content: Word had trickled down in late December to J.D. Gustin, the women’s basketball coach at Dixie State University, a southern Utah college making the leap to N.C.A.A. Division I athletics, that some of his players had misgivings about continuing to play during the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Salmonella Outbreak Is Linked to Wild Birds and Feeders, C.D.C. Says
description: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said 19 people had been sickened in eight states.
content: A salmonella outbreak linked to contact with wild songbirds and bird feeders has sickened 19 people across eight states, eight of whom have been hospitalized, federal health authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens and Julia Jacobs
title: Performing Arts Make a Cautious Return in New York
description: More than a year after the pandemic abruptly shuttered theaters and concert halls across the city, limited audiences were welcomed back inside.
content: The days are getting longer. The sun is out. The number of vaccinated New Yorkers continues to grow every day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: ‘Godzilla vs. Kong’ Roars at the Box Office With $48.5 Million
description: Even though it was streaming at the same time, moviegoers flocked to theaters. But with caps on seating capacity, analysts said, the take was about half of what was normal.
content: Moviegoers sent a message to Hollywood over the weekend: We’re ready to return to theaters — and will buy tickets even if the same film is instantly available in our living rooms — but we want to leave our grim world for a silly fantasy one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: Military Closes Failing Facility at Guantánamo Bay to Consolidate Prisoners
description: The move, which took place in a secret operation over the weekend, was conceived during the Trump administration to save on costs and troops at the remote base in Cuba.
content: U.S. military guards have moved Khalid Shaikh Mohammed and other former C.I.A. prisoners to the main part of the prison compound at Guantánamo Bay from a failing secret facility, in a consolidation of detention operations that could cut costs and reduce the troop presence at the base in Cuba, the military said on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech and Muktita Suhartono
title: Floods and Mudslides in Eastern Indonesia Leave at Least 41 Dead
description: Entire neighborhoods were submerged, with some of the worst effects hitting a remote island accessible only by sea, officials said.
content: The fatal alchemy of mud, water and sheer force struck in eastern Indonesia at an hour past midnight on Sunday, killing at least 41 people, disaster-relief officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason DeParle
title: Biden Effort to Combat Hunger Marks ‘a Profound Change’
description: As millions of Americans lack enough to eat, the administration is rapidly increasing aid — with an eye toward a permanent safety net expansion.
content: WASHINGTON — With more than one in 10 households reporting that they lack enough to eat, the Biden administration is accelerating a vast campaign of hunger relief that will temporarily increase assistance by tens of billions of dollars and set the stage for what officials envision as lasting expansions of aid.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Sunday Read: ‘The Beauty of 78.5 Million Followers’
description: How social media stars like Addison Rae gave the cosmetics industry a makeover.
content: During the pandemic, cheerleader-ish girls performing slithery hip-hop dances to rap music on  TikTok has been the height of entertainment — enjoyed both genuinely and for laughs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff
title: U.S. Looks to Build on Secret Portions of Taliban Deal to Reduce Violence
description: In the final weeks before the U.S. is set to withdraw from Afghanistan, officials are trying to negotiate with the insurgent group and stave off a Taliban spring offensive.
content: DOHA, Qatar — U.S. diplomats are trying to build on parts of the peace deal made with the Taliban last year, specifically the classified portions that outlined what military actions — on both sides — were supposed to be prohibited under the signed agreement, according to American, Afghan and Taliban officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: With Biggest Stars Absent, Miami Open Serves Up Some Chaos
description: Top men’s seeds and Naomi Osaka fell earlier than expected, but there was some normalcy: Ashleigh Barty won in women’s singles, successfully defending her title.
content: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla. — So what exactly happened at the Miami Open over the past two weeks?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Weiyi Cai, Audra D. S. Burch and Jugal K. Patel
title: Swelling Anti-Asian Violence: Who Is Being Attacked Where
description: Using media reports from across the country, The Times found more than 110 episodes since March 2020 in which there was clear evidence of race-based hate.
content: Using media reports from across the country, The Times found more than 110 episodes since March 2020 in which there was clear evidence of race-based hate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Florida Reservoir Breach Could Cause Severe Flooding, Officials Say
description: The authorities in Florida said on Sunday that they were working to drain a leaking reservoir at a former phosphate mine in Manatee County, warning that a full breach could result in a 20-foot wall of water.
content: The authorities in Florida said on Sunday that they were working to drain a leaking reservoir at a former phosphate mine in Manatee County, warning that a full breach could result in a 20-foot wall of water.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: April 4, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, April 4, 2021.
content: An article last Sunday about the pandemic’s effect on our friendships misstated where Rachel Stevens works as a radio producer. It is Seattle, not Bozeman, Mont.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Hold On for a Little While Longer’
description: A reader appeals to grandparents to keep wearing masks and set a good example. Also: The work of mothers.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Getting the I.R.S. to Crack Down on Tax Cheats
description: “When the little people see the big people not paying their fair share, it shatters the social compact,” one reader says. Others urge the hiring of more auditors.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
